reviewText: If you're reading this...you just struck GOLD!This awesome little film really was ahead of it's time!The music is unbelievably cool, Carlos Agosti is fantastic as Count Frankenhausen...a nobleman who has just returned home to his terrified wife as a...vampire!His eyes glow eerily when he's hypnotizing someone and he has a mouth-full of sharp fangs.His coffins open on every side, the castle set is gigantic and he turns into a VERY large...LAUGHING bat!!What else do you want?!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Very good Spanish-language, Mexican-made early 60's horror film.  A vampire controls everyone and all in his household.  His wife, who is still untainted, keeps him at bay at best she can with the help of a loyal servant.  The vampire also has a loyal servant, a skinny Mrs. Danvers-type crone who thinks he is the cat's meow.  Living nearby is a vampire hunter and his minions, an assistant, the hunter's daughter and her fiancé, all who make it their vocation to stop the teether from putting the bite on the whole countryside.  The quality of the DVD is superb.  The black-and-white photography is beautiful.  Highly recommended.  The sequel to this film is La Invasion de los Vampiros (The Invasion of the Vampires).
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a well done Mexican vampire movie. This is the original Mexican version that has vivid black and white. Great clarity. The only problem is it is in Spanish only.  Later on,  K. Gordon Murray added his English Dubbing to this movie, and it was then called "The Bloody Vampire".  The Telefilms version has the English, but the picture and sound is washed out. Too bad you cannot have two dvd players going at the same time, so you could watch "El vampiro Sangreinto" for the picture quality and but listen to "the bloody vampire" so that you could hear the English. You can still follow this one and guess what they are saying. Again, great quality.
summary: Fabulous reprint version. Only bad thinkg is (Spanish Only)  & no K. Gordon Murray English dubbing
Title: N/A

reviewText: This effective gothic Mexican horror film tells the tale of Count Siegfried Frankenhausen,(Carlos Agosti), a sinister Satan-worshipping vampire.  In spite of being thwarted before, Count Frankenhausen has a diabolical desire and plan to spread vampirism throughout Mexico and beyond.  The foe  is the Cagliostro family who are the only ones who know how to stop the Count. Yes, it is silly at times but it does entertain primarily because of the spooky music,  a decent cats, a strong influx of dread and colorful Mexican lore.  Adding to the creativity of the story is the presence of a mortal wife, Frau Eugenia Frankenhausen (Erna Martha Bauman), who has some funny lines and Frau Hildegarde (Bertha Moss), who overacts.  The movie is watchable and will hold your interest.  BTW, the film makes no secret of the fact that there is a sequel coming.I did learn some new vampire lore from this film.  According to the Mexican vampire myth, staking and burning a vampire is a temporary stop but clammic acid is the only permanent fix.  Clammic acid is distilled from the black Mandragora flower and effective against vamparina, the vampire contagion. Night and day pass quickly and the vampire can walk during twilight.  I know that it sounds confusing but it is just movie vampire lore!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an undiscovered gem. It combines 60's Art House movies with Gothic Horror. The sets are great, sort of like Hammer Horror with a Latin inflection. The women are lovely and curvy. The Actor who plays Dracula is convincing and dynamic with a real screen presence. Note this edition has no subtitles in English. But you KNOW the plot anyway, right? The transfer is from a gorgeous black and white print so it's nice not to have the pesky subtitles crowding the scenery. If you're looking for something different with a Dark Shadows/Hammer Horror vibe this is it! Lots of cool slow motion scenes, and the WILDEST fake bat you've ever seen zip through the air!
